column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column3: or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column6: The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.7, as the increased use of renewable fuels and electricity in the transport sector will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions and the promotion of sustainable transportation, which is also a goal of TA4.7.

column2: The share of energy from renewable sources used in transport in the EU reached 9.6 % in 2022, up from 9.1% in 2021.
column5: The progress towards TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.10, as the increased use of renewable energy in transport will contribute to the reduction of fuel intensity in the EU fisheries sector, which is a goal of TA4.10.

column2: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025
column5: The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as the increased use of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector will contribute to the development of renewable hydrogen and the reduction of GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column2: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target
column5: The implementation of TA2.15 may have a negative impact on TA4.3, as the focus on achieving a specific percentage of renewable energy increase by 2022 may divert attention and resources away from the longer-term goal of reducing GHG emissions from shipping, which is a goal of TA4.3.

column2: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector
column5: The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.5, as the increased use of renewable energy in the industry sector will contribute to the development of sustainable aviation fuels and the reduction of GHG emissions in the aviation sector.

column2: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.17 may have a negative impact on TA4.20, as the focus on achieving a specific percentage of electricity interconnection by 2030 may divert attention and resources away from the development of renewable fuels of non-biological origin, which is a goal of TA4.20.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 may have a negative impact on TA4.9, as the focus on reducing energy consumption in public bodies may not directly contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions from transport, which is a goal of TA4.9.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.7, as the reduction of energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions and the promotion of sustainable transportation.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.3, as the reduction of primary energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions from shipping.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings is renovated each year
column5: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as the renovation of buildings will contribute to the development of renewable hydrogen and the reduction of GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column2: Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.26, as the reduction of energy consumption in buildings will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.27, as the increased renovation rate of buildings will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for heavy-duty electric vehicles.

column2: Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels
column5: The implementation of TA2.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as the reduction of energy consumption for heating and cooling will contribute to the development of renewable hydrogen.

column2: Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.26, as the renovation of non-residential buildings will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.27, as the renovation of worst-performing buildings will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for heavy-duty electric vehicles.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock decreases by at least 16% compared to 2020
column5: The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.25, as the reduction of primary energy use in residential buildings will contribute to the development of renewable hydrogen.

column2: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings
column5: The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.7, as the achievement of cumulative end-use energy savings will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions and the promotion of sustainable transportation.

column2: Member States shall ensure that waste management operators achieve a yearly target for the recycling of plastics
column5: The implementation of TA3.51 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as the increased recycling of plastics will contribute to the reduction of waste and the promotion of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector.

column2: At least 20% of the carbon used in the chemical and plastic products should be from sustainable non-fossil sources
column5: The implementation of TA3.52 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as the increased use of sustainable non-fossil sources in chemical and plastic products will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the industry sector.

column2: The yearly average GHG intensity of the energy used on board by a ship during a reporting period shall be reduced
column5: The implementation of TA4.3 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as the reduction of GHG intensity in shipping will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption in public bodies.

column2: Aviation fuel suppliers shall also ensure that Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) made available to aircraft operators at each Union airport will be at least 2% from 2025
column5: The implementation of TA4.5 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22, as the increased use of SAF will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption and GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column2: Each Member State shall set an obligation on fuel suppliers to ensure that the combined share of advanced biofuels and biogas produced from the feedstock listed in Part A of Annex IX and of renewable fuels of non-biological origin in the energy supplied to the transport sector is at least 1 % in 2025
column5: The implementation of TA4.7 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.11, as the increased use of advanced biofuels and biogas will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions and the promotion of sustainable transportation.

column2: Cut the emissions of transport sector by 90% by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA4.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23, as the reduction of GHG emissions in the transport sector will contribute to the reduction of primary energy consumption.

column2: EU fisheries are encouraged to continue the positive trend, as observed for the period 2009-2019, towards reducing fuel intensity
column5: The implementation of TA4.10 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as the reduction of fuel intensity in the EU fisheries sector will contribute to the promotion of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector.

column2: Reduce the average door-to-door cost of combined transport operations by at least 10% within 7 years
column5: The implementation of TA4.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22, as the reduction of transport costs will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption and GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column2: For urban buses, manufacturers shall comply with the 90% minimum shares in their fleet of new heavy-duty vehicles
column5: The implementation of TA4.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.26, as the increased use of electric vehicles will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

column2: The average CO2 emissions of the Union fleet of new heavy-duty motor vehicles shall be reduced
column5: The implementation of TA4.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25, as the reduction of CO2 emissions from heavy-duty vehicles will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption in buildings.

column2: The share of biofuels and biogas produced from the feedstock listed in Part B of Annex IX in the energy content of fuels and electricity supplied to the transport sector shall, except in Cyprus and Malta, be limited to 1.7%
column5: The implementation of TA4.18 may have a negative impact on TA2.11, as the limitation on the use of biofuels and biogas may divert attention and resources away from the promotion of sustainable transportation.

column2: In the first phase, from 2020 up to 2024, the strategic objective is to install at least 6 GW of renewable hydrogen electrolysers in the EU
column5: The implementation of TA4.20 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.24, as the increased production of renewable hydrogen will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, at the end of each year, the following power output targets are met cumulatively
column5: The implementation of TA4.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.26, as the increased production of renewable hydrogen will contribute to the development of recharging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

column2: Member States shall ensure that along the TEN-T core and comprehensive network, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to light-duty vehicles deployed in each direction of travel with a maximum distance of 60 km in-between them
column5: The implementation of TA4.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25, as the development of recharging infrastructure will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption in buildings.

column2: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, along the TEN-T core road network, publicly accessible recharging pools dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles are deployed
column5: The implementation of TA4.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.28, as the development of recharging infrastructure will contribute to the reduction of energy consumption for heating and cooling.
